First, it is important to note that both crocodiles and alligators are amphibious (meaning they can live on land and in water) reptiles and are able to adapt to a range of environments. 

The Great Salt Lake is known for having an extremely high salt concentration, which can be challenging for some animals to survive in. However, both crocodiles and alligators have a unique adaptation that allows them to tolerate saltwater environments. 

When it comes to the question of whether a crocodile would survive longer in the Great Salt Lake than an alligator, it is important to consider their differences in physiology and behavior. 

Crocodiles have a higher tolerance for saltwater than alligators, as they have salt glands located in their tongues that allow them to excrete excess salt. Alligators do not have salt glands and must remove excess salt by urinating. 

Additionally, crocodiles are known to travel greater distances and have a wider range of prey than alligators. This may give them an advantage in the Great Salt Lake, where there may be less prey available compared to other environments. 

Thus, based on these factors, it is likely that a crocodile would survive longer in the Great Salt Lake than an alligator.
